Here's an interesting thing that happened to me. I went to see my doctor on Thurs. I am on a low (5 mg) but typical dose of a blood pressure medication but my blood pressure is running just a bit high. The doctor decided to increase (but not double) my dose, saying that I should take 1 1/2 pills each day. If my blood pressure came down too low, I should go back to 1 / day. So I took my prescription for 45 pills for 30 days to the pharmacy. The insurance company for my Medicare Part D Rx plan rejected the prescription. The reason they gave was that it exceeded the number of pills for my plan.
 
 Not the dosage but the number of pills. I could have 30 pills for the month - not 45. I could have 30 5 mg. pills or 30 10 mg. pills. In fact, I could have 100 10 mg. pills if the doctor wrote that. I just couldn't have 45 5 mg. pills - there is a pill limit on 5 mg. pills. I specifically asked what the dosage limit was and the answer was that there isn't any dosage limit, only a pill limit.
 
 I got the 30 pills and will get 15 more "sample" pills from the doctor. I will also get a new Part D insurance carrier. I already checked with BC/BS and they don't count pills and I won't end up paying any more in the long run.
 
 I cancelled Aetna Part D Rx Plan. They have rejected at least 4 prescriptions in the last couple of months, requiring that I call the doctor to try to get something else.

More evidence that the US healthcare system is screwed up. In the UK you get whatever the doctor prescribes, and it costs you the same amount regardless, up to a maximum of GBP90 a year if you're on regular medication.
